definitions.definition: rather; to some extent
definitions.labels: (especially British English)British EnglishNorth American EnglishBritish English

examples.text: These trousers are a bit tight.
‘Are you tired?’ ‘Yes, I am a bit.’
I was a bit disappointed by the film.
It costs **a bit more** than I wanted to spend.
The future looks **a little bit** brighter this morning.
I felt **a wee bit** guilty about it.
I can lend you fifty pounds, if you want. That should help a bit.
I'm still just a bit confused.
He helped me a little bit in the afternoon.

definitions.definition: a short time or distance

examples.text: Wait a bit!
Can you move up a bit?
Greg thought for a bit before answering.
See you in a bit.

definitions.definition: a small amount or piece of something

examples.text: Here are some useful **bits of information**.
I have a **bit of** good **news** for you.
Let me give you **a little bit** of advice.
With **a bit of luck**, we'll be there by 12.
I've got a bit of shopping to do.
bits of paper/wood/plastic
Here's a bit of news that may interest you.
Do you want a bit of pizza?
Can you save me a bit?
A big bit of plaster just fell down from the ceiling.
She tore the letter up and threw it on the floor. Marion stooped to pick up the bits.
I've bought a nice bit of fish for dinner.
I'm worried because bits keep falling off my car.
He managed to get odd bits of work, but no regular job.

definitions.definition: a part of something larger

examples.text: The best bit of the holiday was seeing the Grand Canyon.
I read it, but I missed out the boring bits.
I like the bit about owls in the first chapter.
Listen to the interview again and pick out the bits you want to use in the article.
The school play was a huge success—the audience roared with laughter at all the funny bits.

definitions.definition: a large amount

examples.text: ‘How much does he earn?’ **‘Quite a bit!’**
It rained **a fair bit** during the night.
The new system will **take a bit of** getting used to *(= it will take a long time to get used to)*.
‘Has it been difficult for you at work?’ ‘Just a bit (= it has been very difficult).’
We made a good bit of progress.

definitions.definition: the smallest unit of information used by a computer
a metal bar that is put in a horse’s mouth so that the rider can control it
a tool or part of a tool for drilling (= making) holes
an amount of money equal to 12½ cents
a person’s sexual organs
to be very sad or worried

examples.text: Inside I'm in bits because I miss him so much.
I’m in bits about the problems I’ve had.
She was in bits over her decision to quit.

definitions.definition: behaviour or ideas that are typical of a particular group, type of person or activity

examples.text: She couldn't accept the whole drug-culture bit.

definitions.definition: a piece at a time; gradually

examples.text: He assembled the model aircraft bit by bit.
Bit by bit memories of the night came back to me.

definitions.definition: not fair or not reasonable

examples.text: It's a bit much calling me at three in the morning.
The noise from next door is getting a bit much.

definitions.definition: used when talking about unpleasant or negative things or ideas, to mean ‘rather a…’

examples.text: We may have a bit of a problem on our hands.
The rail strike is a bit of a pain.

definitions.definition: a person that you think is sexually attractive
a person of a low social class who has a sexual relationship with somebody of a higher class
the boyfriend or girlfriend of somebody who is already married or in a steady sexual relationship with somebody else

examples.text: Is he your bit on the side?

definitions.definition: small objects or items of various kinds

examples.text: She stuffed all her bits and pieces into a bag and left.
I just need to get a few bits and pieces at the supermarket.

definitions.definition: to use bombs or other weapons to destroy somebody/something completely

examples.text: The plane was blown to pieces when the bomb exploded.

definitions.definition: impatient to do or start doing something

examples.text: Gerry’s champing at the bit to go to college.

definitions.definition: to do your share of a task

examples.text: We can finish this job on time if everyone does their bit.

definitions.definition: just as good, bad, etc.; equally good, bad, etc.

examples.text: Rome is every bit as beautiful as Paris.
He’s every bit as clever as she is.

definitions.definition: to become very enthusiastic about something that you have started to do so that you are unlikely to stop until you have finished
not at all; not in any way

examples.text: ‘Are you cold?’ ‘Not a bit.’
It's not a bit of use *(= there's no point in)* complaining.
I'm not the least bit interested in football.
I don't like that idea one bit.

definitions.definition: used for saying that something that you had expected to happen did not happen

examples.text: You'd think she'd be tired after the journey but not a bit of it!

definitions.definition: not any

examples.text: He didn't **take a blind bit of notice** of me *(= he ignored me)*.
It won't **make the blindest bit of difference** *(= it will make no difference at all)*.

definitions.definition: not at all

examples.text: Normally I'm not the least bit shy.
He wasn't the slightest bit interested in answering our questions.

definitions.definition: into small pieces

examples.text: The book fell to bits in my hands.
All the crockery had been smashed to bits.
She took the engine to bits, then carefully put it together again.

definitions.definition: very much

examples.text: I love my kids to bits.
She was **thrilled to bits** when I said I'd come.

wordOrigin: senses 1 to 5 and senses 9 to 10 Old English bita ‘bite, mouthful’, of Germanic origin; related to German Bissen, also to bite.senses 7 to 8 Old English bite ‘biting, a bite’, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch beet and German Biss, also to bite.sense 6 1940s: blend of binary and digit.
